bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: Sacred Stories 19: Wampum-Head and His Nephews

p.seg: pêyak ôtênaw êh-misâk , kayâs êsa êh-môtocik . There was a certain large town, of old, when, as we are told, they ate each other.

êkosi awa iskwêw êh-okimâwit , piyêsiw-iskwêw , napatê ôtênaw êh-tipêyihtahk , êkwah napatê ôtênaw êh-tipêyihtahk êwakô okimâw mahîhkan ; nâpêw êôkô . And there a woman was chief, a Thunderbird-Woman, who ruled over one-half of the town; and over the other half there ruled as chief a Wolf; a man was this one.

otôskinîkîmiwâwa êh-astwâtocik , êh-mêtawêcik , êh-manitôwi-mêtawêcik , pêyak siyâkôcihihcih , êkosi owîcêwâkanah êh-nipahimiht , êh-môwimiht , êkosi piko
êh-môtocik
isiyîhkâtêw . They used their followers as prizes of the contest, of their manitou contests, so that, whenever one was defeated, then his followers were killed and eaten; that is what is called “eating each other.”
nanâtohk , ôki ayîsiyiniwak kâ-itwêhk , nanâtohk pisiskiwak êyôkonik . Various kinds, those who were called men, various kinds of beasts they were.
êkos êôkô . That is the way it was.

êkwah awa mahîhkan k-ôkimâwit , êkotah ohci pêyak oskinîkiskwêw , osîmisah , nâpêsisah êh-apisîsisiyit , ê-kitimâkêyimât , ê-sâkihât , Then in the part where the Wolf was chief, a young woman from there, who had a small brother whom she cared for and loved,

ôhtâwiya okâwiya kotakah wîcisâna kahkiyaw êh-nipahimiht , wiyawâ piko nîso ê-pimâtisicik osîmisa , ômis îtêyihtam :
nika-sipwêhtân ; when her father and mother and all her other brothers and sisters had been killed, and only the two, she and her little brother were left alive, then thus she thought: “I shall go away;
nisîmis awa mâskôc wîh-pimâtisicih , êh-itêyihtahk ; perhaps it will be possible for my little brother here to live,” she thought;
osâm kitimâkisiw , êh-apisîsisit , itêyihtam ; “He is too pitiful, the little fellow,” she thought;
hâw , anohc kâ-tipiskâk , mistahi ta-mâyi-kîsikâw ! ta-mispon ! itwêw ; “So then, tonight let there be very bad weather! Let it snow!” she said;

seg.gloss: “I shall go away and no one shall know whither I go.”

p.seg: êkosi itêyihtam . So she thought.
tâpwê êh-tipiskâk , mistahi mâyi-kîsikâw , êh-mispohk . Really, when night ell, there was very bad weather, and it snowed.
êkwah miywêyihtam aw ôskinîkiskwêw . Then the young woman was glad.

mayaw mistah êh-tipiskâk , wawêyîw , wîkiwâw êh-manisahk , ispimihk itah êh-mâyâtahk êh-wêpinahk . As soon as it was very dark, she made ready; she cut down her lodge and threw it aloft into the storm.

êkwah otanâskânah , otakôhpah , kahkiyaw ta-kîh-âpacihtât kêkwayah otinam , êh-kîsi-wawêyît , mostoswayân êkotah êh-wêwîkahpitahk ocayânisah . And her sleeping-mats and her blanket-robes and all the things she would have occasion to use, she took, when she had made ready, and she wrapped all her possessions in a buffalo robe.

êkos îsi ê-sipwêhtêw , êh-otâpêt ôh ôcayânisah , tâpiskôc nipakitâpânâsk , êkos îsi êh-otâpêt , êkwah osîmisah êh-nayômât . si mistahê mâyi-kîsikâyiw . In this way she set out, dragging her belongings, dragging them as if on a flat sled, and carrying her little brother.
kapê-tipisk mâyi-kîsikâyiw , êh-pimohtêt . The storm kept on all night, while she walked on.
piyisk wâpaniyiw ; âhci pikoh mâyi-kîsikâyiw . At last day dawned; the bad weather did not abate.
iyikohk êh-otâkosik , êkoyikohk astê-kîsikâw . All that day it stormed. [sic] Only towards evening the day grew clear.
âhci pikoh pimohtêw . She kept on walking.
piyis tipiskâw . At last night fell.
êkotah êkwah kapêsiw . At that point she camped.
nama kêkway mîciw , êkotah êh-nipât . She had nothing to eat, there where she slept.
êyikohk êh-wâpaniyik , mîna sipwêhtêw . When day broke, she went on.
êh-wâpaniyik , êkwah mâtoyiwa osîmisa , êh-nôhtêkatêyit . Then, when day broke, her little brother cried, because he was hungry.
êkosi nicawâc wawêyîw , ê-sipwêhtêt . Yet she needs made ready to go on.

êyikohk êh-miskahk itah êh-ayapâskwêyâyik , êkotah pêyak mistah êh-sakâyik , êkotah itohtêw , êh-nanâtawâpahtahk ,
itah ê-miywâsik ta-wîkiyân , êh-itêyihtahk . When she had found a stretch of country that was dotted with clumps of trees, where there was one larger grove, thither she went, to look it carefully over, thinking, “I shall try to find a good place to live.”
tâpwê miskam sakâhk êy-ihkatawâyik , êh-nipîwiyik , wâsakâm mistah êh-sakâyik , êkotah kapêsiw . Really, she did find in the wood a hollow place where there was water and dense forest round about.
pânaham , êkotah ê-wîh-wîkit ; êkwah kotawêw . There she pitched camp. She cleared off the snow where she meant to dwell; she built a fire.
âhci pikoh mâtoyiwa osîmisah , ê-nôhtêhkatêyit . Her little brother still was weeping with hunger.
ê-kîh-kotawêt , êkwah osîhtâw ê-wîh-tâpakwêt . When she had built the fire, she made something to use as a snare.
êkwah mihtah êh-otinahk , êkotah k-ôtinahk mihtah , tapasiyiwa êkotah ohci wâposwah . Then, as she gathered faggots, from the place where she gathered faggots, some rabbits scampered forth.
êyakonih tâpakwâsoyiwa pêyak . One of them got caught in the snare.
nipahêw . She killed it.
hây hây ! êkwah nisîmis kê-mîcisot ! itêyihtam . “Splendid! Now my little brother shall eat!” she thought.
kîwêhtahêw ; iyâyaw osîhêw , ê-wîh-kîsiswât , ê-wîh-asamât osîmisah . She took it back with her; eagerly she prepared it to cook, that she might give her brother to eat.
êkosi êh-kîsiswât , pêkopayiyiwa osîmisa . When she had cooked it done, her little brother awoke.
êkosi êyakoni asamêw . So she gave him food.
êkwah wiya pasikôw , êh-âwatât mihtah , ê-wîh-osihtât wîkiwâw . Then she got up and fetched sticks to build their lodge.
piyis mistahih otinam mistikwah . In the end she had got many sticks.
ikoyikohk wîh-mâtoyiwa osîmisah , êkwah ê-nahapîstawât , êh-kâkîcihât . By this time her little brother was again on the verge of crying, so she sat down by him and consoled him.
êkwah êkotah ay-ayâw . There she remained.

iyikohk êkâ êh-mâtoyit âsay , osîhtâw wîkiwâw , maskosiyah êh-manisahk , êyakonih mîna êh-apahkwêt wîkiwâhk , mîna êh-anâskêt . As soon as he had ceased to weep, she built their lodge, cutting grasses with which she thatched the lodge and made matting for underfoot.

êkoyikohk ê-wîh-tipiskâk , âsay t-êsi-kîsôwâyik êy-îsîhtât wîkih , êkwah pîhtokahêw osîmisa , êkwah êh-kotawêt pîhcâyihk . By this time darkness was at hand, but she had built her lodge so that it would be warm; and now she took her little brother inside, and built a fire within.
mwêhcih êh-pahkisimoyik , kâh-matwê-ma-mawimoyit wâposwah . Just at sunset she heard a rabbit squeal.
itohtêw : pôtih pêyak . She went there: there was one.
nipahêw . She killed it.
miywêyihtam . She was glad.
êkosi namoya ta-nôhtêhkatêw nisîmis , itêyihtam . “So my little brother will not go hungry,” she thought.
ay-apiw . She sat there.

êkwah ê-tipiskâyik , mâ-mitonêyihtam ,
pitanê êkâ ohcih awiyak miskawit ! êy-itêyihtahk ; Then, in the night she meditated, thinking, “Would that no one might ever find me!
kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwak êkos is âyâwak êtokê ? êh-itêyihtahk ; Are all persons, I wonder, even so?” she thought;

itê k-ôh-itohtêt ôhi ayîsiyiniwah kây-itâtisiyit , kâ-nâh-nipahitoyit , êh-môtoyit ,
êkosi êtokê kotakak mîna is âyâwak ? êy-itêyihtahk , êyako ohci k-ôh-itwêt . the way those people were in the place whence she had come, they who always killed and ate each other, because she thought, “Are others, I wonder, that way too?” was why she spoke thus.

tâpwê miywêyihtam êh-pêyakot ,
êkosi mâskôc nk-ôhpikihâw nisîmis , êh-itêyihtahk . Truly, she was glad to be alone, for she thought, “In this way, perhaps I shall bring up my little brother.

êkotah tahto-kîsikâw mihtah êh-otinahk , mîna êh-tâpakwêt êh-mihcêtiyit wâposwah , tâpwê têpiskâyikih , kâh-nipâcih , wiyâpahk êh-nâtât wâposwah , mitoni miywêyihtam mâh-mihcêt êh-nipahât . There every day she gathered firewood and snared many rabbits; and truly, after each night, when she had slept and in the morning fetched the rabbits, she was very glad that she continued to kill many of them.
piyisk osîhtâw wiyawitimihk itah ê-wîh-akotât wâposwah , osâm mihcêt êh-nipahât . At last she built out of doors something on which to hang the rabbits, having killed so many.
hâw , êkos êcik ôma êkâ mayaw kê-nôhtêhkatêyâhk nisîmis ! itêyihtam . “Well, and so now my little brother and I shall not too soon be hungry!” she thought.

nama kêkway kotak atoskâtam , nayêstaw êh-tâpakwêt êkwah mihtah êh-otinahk , êkotah oma k-ây-ayât ,
pitan ôma êkâ ohcih miskawit awiyak ! êh-itêyihtahk . She worked at nothing but snaring rabbits and bringing wood, and concerning that place where she was, she thought, “Would that no one might ever find me!”
kîtahtawê êkwah , kinwêsk itah êh-ayât êkwah , osîmisah êkwah misikitiyiwa . Then in time, when she had been there a long while, her brother grew larger.
êkwah osîhtâw acosisah , osîmisah êy-osîhtawât , ê-wîh-kakwê-nihtâh-pimotahkwêhât . Then she made arrows for her brother, meaning to teach him to be a good marksman.
piyisk nakacihtâw kêkway ta-wîh-kakwê-nipahât awa nâpêsis . in time the lad became skilled to the point where he wanted to try to kill something.
kîtahtawê sakâhk êh-papâmohtêt awa nâpêsis , wâpamêw wâposwah . Presently, as he walked about in the wood, he saw a rabbit.
ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahât , tâpwê nipahêw . When he tried to kill it, really, he killed it.
ha , miywêyihtam , êh-pîhtokahât . He was glad, and brought it into the lodge.
hây hây ! itwêw awa oskinîkiskwêw ; “Splendid!” said the young woman;

êkos êcik âni êkâ kê-kîh-nipahâhkatosoyâhk , âsay êh-nipahât nisîmis wâposwah , itêyihtam . “And so now there will be no danger of our starving, now that my little brother is killing rabbits,” she thought.

êkwah tâpwê kotakah osîhtâw acosisah , nawac êh-misâyikih ,
kêkway cit-ôh-miyo-nipahtât , êy-itêyihtahk . And so she made some more arrows, larger ones, thinking, “So that he can do well at killing things with them.”

piyisk êh-kîsihtât , êkwah êyakonih êh-âpacihtât awa nâpêsis , tâpwê mâh-mihcêt nipahêw wâposwah . At last, when she had finished them, and the lad was using them, really he killed many and many rabbits.

êkwah aw îskwêw pîkonam apâhkwâson , êy-osihtât osîma cit-ôtâsiyit , mîna t-ôskotâkayit . Then the woman tore pieces from the tent-covering and made something for her brother to wear as breeches and as a shirt.
êkwah kêkâc oskinîkiw awa nâpêsis . By this time the lad was almost a young man.
mistahi miyosiw awa nâpêsis . He was very handsome.

êkwah êkotah ôm êh-ay-ayâcik , kîtahtawê wâposwah ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamât , ê-papâmohtêt , kâh-mâtâhât pêyak apisi-môsosah . Then, as they dwelt there, presently, as he was walking about, trying to get sight of rabbits, he came upon the track of a dwarf moose.

kîkway awa ? itêyihtam ;
mahtih nika-kakwê-wâpamâw , itêyihtam . “What kind of creature is this?” he thought; “Suppose I try to get a look at him,” he thought.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât . Presently he saw it.

kêkway awa ? itêyihtam ;
mahtih kê-kîh-nipahak , itêyihtam . “What kind of creature is this?” he thought; “Let me see if I can kill him,” he thought.
tâpwê pimwêw ; tâpwê nipahêw . So he shot an arrow at it; really, he killed it.
êh-otihtât , namoya nisitawêyimêw kîkwayah ôhi . When he went up to it, he did not know what manner of beast it was.

mahtih nika-kîwêhtahâw ; mahtih kê-nisitawêyimât nimis
itêyihtam . “Let me take him home; let me see if my big sister knows him,” he thought.
kîwêhtahêw , êh-otâpêt , êh-takohtahât wîkiwâhk . He took it home, dragging it, and brought it to their dwelling.
nimisê , mâcikôcitân kîkwayah awa ? itêw . “Big sister, come, see; what sort of creature is this?” he said to her.
êh-wayawît aw ôskinîkiskwêw , sêmâk nisitawêyimêw . When the young woman came out, at once she recognized it.
hây hây ! êkwah kê-miyo-mîcisoyahk , nisîmis ! apsi-môsos awa , itik . “Splendid! Now we shall have good eating, little brother! This is a dwarf moose,” she told him.

seg.gloss: “Ho!”

p.seg: miywêyihtam . He was glad.
êkwah êwakonih kiy-omaskisinit nisîmis , itwêw aw oskinîkiskwêw , êh-wiyinihât . “And from this creature my brother can have moccasins,” said the young woman, as she set about skinning it.
tâpwê êyakonih môwêwak êkwah . So then they ate it.
êkosi nama kêkway êkwah wiyah tâpakwêw aw îskwêw ; ayis osîma êkwah nâh-nipahêyiwa wâposwa . And now the woman no longer set snares; for now her brother continued to kill rabbits.

tâpwê ôhi osihêw aw îskwêw , ê-wih-ocit-ômaskisiniyit osîma . So now the woman prepared that creature, that her brother might have moccasins of it. LB on {ê-wih-ocit-ômaskisiniyit}: The prefix ocit is probably an error.

êh-kîh-nipâcik , êh-wâpahk , êh-waniskât aw oskinîkiskwêw , âsay namwâc nipâyiwa osîma , êh-mâciyit . When they had slept, in the morning when the young woman got up, her brother was by no means still asleep, but had gone hunting.
êh-pônih-âpihtâ-kîsikâk , âsay osîmah takohtêyiwa ; nîso apisi-môsosah pêsiwêyiwa . In the afternoon her brother arrived; he brought two dwarf moose.
hây hây ! itwêw aw oskinîkiskwêw ; “Splendid!” said the young woman;
êkos êcik ôma êkâ kê-kîh-nôhtêhkatêyahk ! itêyihtam ; “And so now we shall never need to go hungry!” she thought;
êyakoni nisîmis êkwah t-ôtâsiw , itêyihtam . “Now of these creatures my brother shall have breeches,” she thought.
êkosi ê-kîh-kîsi-wiyininihât , êkwah iyâyaw asamêw osîma . So, when she had finished skinning them and cutting them up, with zeal then she gave her brother his food.

nama wiya wîhkâc êkwah kitotik osîma , osâm êh-nêpêwisiyit ta-kitotikot , êkwah êh-oskinîkiyit . Never now did her brother address her, for he was too bashful to speak to her, now that he was a young man. LB: The tabu against naming and speech between brother and sister seems to have lost its force on Sweet Grass; it is violated below in this story. The tabu is maintained on Star Blanket Reserve.

tâpwê mîna êh-wâpaniyik , kiksêpâ êh-waniskât , sâsay êsah kâ-sipwêhtêyit osîma , êh-mâciyit , êkwah wiya ôhi iyâyaw apisi-môsoswayânah êy-osîhât , mitâsah ê-wîh-osîhtât . Then, the next morning early, when she arose, she saw that again her brother had already gone away to hunt; she, for her part, set zealously to work preparing the hides of the dwarf moose, to make breeches.
êh-otâkosiniyik , êh-kîsihât , apisi-môsoswayânah , kâ-takosiniyit osîma . Toward evening, when she had finished tanning the dwarf-moose skins, her brother arrived.
âsay mîna nîso pêsiwêyiwa apsi-môsosah . Again he was bringing two dwarf moose.
miywêyihtam aw oskinîkiskwêw . The young woman rejoiced.
piyis mîna tipiskâyiw . Soon night came.
êkoyikohk êh-kîsi-atoskâtât ôh apisi-môsoswayânah , êh-pâswât . By this time she had finished working the hides of the dwarfmoose, and was drying them.
êkosi têpiskâyikih êh-kaskikwâsot , osîma êy-osîhtowât ayôwinisah . So then, of nights she would sew, making clothes for her brother.

piyisk mîna mostoswah nipahêyiwa pêyak , êh-pêsiwâyit ,
kîkway êtokê ? êh-itêyihtahk aw ôskinîkiw . At last he killed also a buffalo, and brought it home, thinking, “What kind of beast is this?”

mâka nama wîhkâc êkwah pîkiskwâtitôwak , pikoh aciyaw êh-kitâpamât aw îskwêw osîma ,
tâpwê mistahi miyosiw nisîmis , êh-itêyihtahk ; but now they never spoke to each other, only that the woman would look for a moment at her brother and think, “Truly, my brother is very handsome,”
tâpwê miywâsin ê-kîh-pê-sipwêhtahak nisîm , êy-itêyihtahk . and, “Truly, it is well that I brought my brother off here.”
tahto-kîsikâw êh-mâcît aw ôskinîkiw , pisisik mostoswa mâh-misiwê êh-pêcitâpêt , The youth hunted every day, and dragged home buffalo always entire;

hâh , mîna mayaw piyêsiwâcih mostoswah , wiyâpahkih êsay êh-kîsihât aw îskwêw mostoswayânah , êh-otanâskânicik , mîna êh-otakohpicik osîma , as soon as he would bring a buffalo, by the next morning, the woman had already prepared the buffalo hide, for sleeping robes and robes to wear, for her brother and for herself.
kîtahtawê kîkisêpâ êh-waniskât aw îskwêw , kêyâpic nipâyiwa osîma . And then one morning, when she got up, her brother was still asleep.
ê-kiskêyimikot êh-kîsi-paminawasot , waniskâyiwa . When he knew that she had finished cooking, he got up.
âkosi êkwah ê-mîcisocik . So then they ate.

ê-kîsi-mîcisocik , êkoyikohk wayawîw aw ôskinîkiw , êh-nitawi-kîskatahwât asâmâhtikwah , ê-wîh-osîhât asâma , mîna êh-wanîhikêt , nîso êy-osîhtât wanîhikanah . When they had eaten, the youth went out of doors, to cut sticks for snowshoes which he intended to make, and to set traps, two traps which he had built.

iyikohk êh-takohtêt , êh-wâpahtahk aw îskwêw mistikwah êh-pîhtokatâyit , ê-kîh-asamât , êkwah otinam ôhi mistikwah aw îskwêw , êh-tîhkisahk . When he came back when the woman saw that he was bringing sticks of wood, after giving him his meal, the woman took the sticks, and melted some fat. LB on {êh-tîhkisahk}: If the verb is really {tihkisam}: “he melts it,” the object would seem to be the sticks.

êh-kîsi-mîcisot aw ôskinîkiw , êh-môhkotahk , asâma êy-osihât , êkoyikohk kiskêyihtam aw îskwêw êh-osîhâyit asâma . When the youth had eaten, and was whittling the sticks to make snowshoes, then the woman knew that he was making snowshoes.
êkwah osîhtâw ôma pahkêkin , ê-wîh-wâskâsahk aw iskwêw . Then she prepared that rawhide for cutting round the edge.
tâpwê êh-wâpahk , êh-ntawâpahtahk owanihikanah , pêyak tasôhêw kihîwa , êkwah pêyak nikikwa . Then, the next morning, when he went to look at his traps, he had trapped an eagle and an otter.

seg.gloss: “Ha!”

p.seg: êwakoni mîkwanah kahkiyaw otinêw . He took all the feathers.
êkwah ôhi kihîwa pahkonêw aw îskwêw , êh-pâswât . And the woman skinned the otter, and dried the skin. LB on {kihîwa}: Doubtless a slip of the tongue for {nikikwa}; so translated.
mâskôc ê-wîh-otastotinit nisîm , itêyihtam . “No doubt my brother wants a head-dress,” she thought.
piyisk êkwah osîhêyiwa asâma . Then he made also his snowshoes.
êh-kîs-ôsîhât , êkwah awa iskwêw otinêw , êh-askimâtât oh âsama , êh-pâswât . When he had done making them, the woman took the snowshoes and threaded them with the thongs, and dried them.

êkosi êh-kîsi-pâsôyit , kîksêpâ iyikoh mîna êh-waniskât , kayâhtê mâka mîna namoya nipâyiwa osîma , âsay êh-mâciyit , ê-wîh-ây-atoskêt wayawîtimihk , pahkêkinwah êh-ay-osîhtât ,
êh-miywâsik nik-ôsîhtân nîkinân , êh-itêyihtahk . And so, when they had dried, when in the morning she got up, again her brother no longer slept, but had gone hunting; so she went about her work outside the lodge, tanning hides, thinking, “I shall improve our dwelling.”
iyikohk êh-otâkosihk , wayawîtimihk êh-nîpawit , kîkway kâ-pêhtahk . Towards evening, as she stood outside the door, she heard something.
êh-ntotahk , pôti kâ-pê-nikamoyit awiya ; itêyihtam . As she listened, it appeared that someone was singing as he came; so it seemed to her.
nisîm êtokê , itêyihtam . “I wonder if it is my brother,” she thought.
êh-pîhtokêt , kiyipah âsay kisiwâk kâ-pêtwêwîtamiyit . When she went inside, quickly from close by came the sound of that person.
kisiwâk êh-pêy-ayâyit , kîskôwêyiwa . When he had come near, he broke off his song.
pôtih osîma kâ-matwê-takosiniyit . It was her brother, coming home with song.
mihtah itah êh-astêyikih , êkotah êh-têhciwêpinâyit otasâmiyiwa , kâ-kitôyit . Where the faggots lay, on top there he threw his snowshoes, and as he did so, they gave a call.
êyôkonik êcik kâ-pê-nikamocik ! itêyihtam aw îskwêw . “And so it is they who came a-singing!” thought the woman.
pôtih êh-wayawît , pisisik askêkin kâ-pêtâyit . When she went out, he was bringing nothing but fresh hides.

êh-otinât , êh-wâ-wâpahtahk , pôt ês iyâpêyisah kâ-wâpamât , êskana êh-kikamoyit , êkwah waskasiyiwa . When she took it, and looked at it, she saw that it was the skin of a young bull, with the horns and the hoofs.
êyakonih mâh-maniswêw , ohpim ê-ahât . These she cut off, and laid them aside.
askêkin min oma mihtihk têhtastâw . The hide she laid also on top of the firewood.
ê-wîh-otakôhpit êtokê , itêyihtam . “Doubtless he wants a blanket-robe,” she thought.
êskanah ôhi mînah owaskasiyiwa pîhtokahêw , êh-ahât . The horns and the hoofs she brought indoors and put them down.

êkwah êh-kîsi-mîcisot aw ôskinîkiw , otinêw ôh êskanah , iskotêhk cîk êkotah êh-ahât , ê-wîh-kêcikwahahk anih ôskanah . Then, when the young man had eaten, he took the horns and placed them close to the fire, to take out the bone.
piyis kahkiyaw otinam anih ôskanah . At last he took all the bone.
piyis kawisimôw . Then he went to bed.
êh-wâpahk pêyakwanohk apiw ; namoya mâcîw , êh-osîhât êskanah . The next morning, he sat in one place; he did not hunt, but prepared the horns.

êkwah aw îskwêw ôhi mostoswayânah êh-osîhât , êhwah ,
nôhtêhkatêtokê ! êy-itêyimât osîma , ôhtapiwinihk k-ôh-pasikoyit osîma . And the woman, preparing the buffalo robe, just as she thought of her brother, “He must be hungry!” even then her brother rose from his settee.

êkosi êkotah ,
tânêhk êtokê ? itêyihtam . Then, “I wonder what is the matter!” she thought.
êkwah aw ôskinîkiw ê-kîh-wîh-kimotamawât omisah mîkisisah . But it was because that youth meant to steal his sister's wampum-beads.

êkosi ,
kîkway êtokê ? itêyihtam aw îskwêw . So, “What can it be?” thought the woman.
piysk kîsihêw ôh êskanah aw osinîkiw , mîn ôhi waskasiyah . At last the youth finished preparing the horns and the hoofs.
êh-tipiskâk kîsihêw aw îskwêw mostoswayânah . By nightfall the woman finished the buffalo robe.

iyikohk êh-wâpahk , êkoyihohk kikamohêw aw ôskinîkiw ôh êskanah , mîn ôhi waskasiyiwa , ê-wih-otakohpit aw oskinîkiw . When the next day dawned, the youth attached to it the horns and the hoofs, to make him a blanket-robe.

ômis îtêw ômisa :
nimisê , mîkisisak cî kitayâwâwak êh-wâpiskisicik , êkwah ê-askêhtakosicik ? itêw . He said to his sister, “Sister, have you wampum beads that are white, and some that are blue?” he asked her.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg: êkosi aw îskwêw otinêw , êh-itisinamawât . Accordingly, she took them and handed them to him.

êkwah aw oskinîkiw ê-sîkahot , êh-kîsi-sîkahot , ôhi mîkisisah êh-pâh-pôtâtât , mâh-mihcêtiyiwa kâ-wâpiskisiyit ôhi mîkisisah ôtah ostikwânihk , napatê wêscakâsah Zkahkiyaw ê-tâpiskahwât mîkisisah , Then the youth combed his hair, and when he had combed it, breathed upon those beads, whereupon a great many of those white wampum-beads were on his head there; he had threaded all the hairs on one side of his head with the beads, CHECK tapiskahwat

tâpiskôc êh-wâpistikwânêt napatê , êkwah napatê ôhi k-âskîhtakosiyit mîkisisah êh-itamoyit ostikwânihk , êh-mîkisistikwânêt . just as though his hair were white, and on the other side the blue beads were strung on his head; he was a Wampum-Head.

êkwah tâpwê miyosiw aw oskinîkiw : oskotâkay êh-pimikitêyik , sihkosiwayânah êh-kikamoyit , mîna otâsihk êh-kikamoyikih , êh-pîmikitêyikih , mîn êkotah sihkosiwayanah êh-kikamoyit , Then truly handsome was that young man; his coat was ornamented with quill-work and with tassels of weasel skins, and some were on his breeches, and they, too, had quill-work, and they had weasel-skins on them,

êkwah ôhi nikikwayânah êh-otastotinit , otakohpah êskanah êh-kikamoyit êkwah waskasiyiwa êkotah êh-kikamoyit . and he had a headgear of that otterskin, and on his robe were horns, and hoofs were on it.
êkwah tâpwê miyosiw aw ôskinîkiw , êkosi êkwah êh-kîsi-nânapâcihisot . Then truly handsome was that youth, when in this guise he had decked himself.

êkotah êkwah tahto-kîsikâw êkwah êh-mâcît , tahto-kîsikâw pêyak êh-nipahât mostoswah , piyis mistahi mîciwin ayâwak . Then, as he hunted each day, and each day killed a buffalo, in time they had a plenty of food.

kîtahtawê kinwêsk êkwah itah itah êh-ayâcik , kîtahtawê nama wiyah wîh-mâcîw aw oskinîkiw , pêyakwanohk êh-apit . Then at one time, when they had long dwelt there, then presently the youth did not care to hunt, but sat still in one place.
iyâtah-asamâci osîmah , namoya wîh-mîcisôw aw ôskinîw , tahk êh-kamwâtapit . Although she gave her brother food, the youth would not eat, but sat listlessly there.

ômis îtêyihtam aw îskwêw :
kêhcinâh wîsakêyihtam nisîm , itêyihtam . The woman thought, “Surely my brother is in pain.”
piyisk nîso-kîsikâw namoya nântaw itohtêw aw oskinîkiw , tahkih êh-kamwâtapit . At last two days passed and the youth had not gone anywhere, but sat all the time inactive.

kîtahtawê ômis îtêw aw îskwêw :
a nisîmis , êh-wîsakêyihtaman cî ? Then the woman asked him, “Brother, are you in pain?
kikaskêyihtamihin , êkâ êh-mîcisoyan , itêw . You make me sad, not eating,” she told him.
namoya , itwêw aw oskinîkiw . “No,” said the youth.
êkosi namoya wîhtamawêw kêkway . Thus he did not tell her what it was.

êh-wâpahk , mînah êh-waniskâcik , êh-kîsi-mîcisocik ,
hâw , nimisê , ôma k-êsinâkosiyân , k-êsîhoyân , êkosi ct-êsinâkosiw oskinîkiw ; The next morning, when they got up and had eaten, “Now then, my sister, even as I look, even as I am dressed, so a young man will look;

seg.gloss: even his snowshoes will look so.
From the direction of noon that youth will come.
Here by the door he will place his snowshoes.
‘Come, my wife, I have come to fetch you!’ he will say to you.
When thus he speaks to you, do not address him.

p.seg: ê-wîh-pê-mawinêhot êyakw âwa oskinîkiw , itêw omisah ; One who comes to challenge me is that youth,” he told his sister;

niwîh-mâcîn ôtêh isi êkâ êh-pîsimowik ; êkotê kâkikê k-êsi-mâciyân , êkotê nk-ôhtohtân , itêw ômisah ; “I shall hunt over here, in the direction where the sun never goes; from this direction, where always I do my hunting, from this direction I shall come,” he told his sister;

kîspin kitotaci , nka-sâkôcihik ; mâka êkâ kitotaci , êkosi nka-sâkôcihâw , itêw ômisah ; “If you speak to him, he will defeat me; but if you do not speak to him, then I shall defeat him,” he told his sister.
kwayask âpihtâ-kîsikâki , êkospi kâ-wih-takohtêt , itêw omisa . “Exactly at noon, that is when he will come,” he told his sister.
êkosi êh-wawêyît , êh-mâcît . With that he went out of the lodge, on his hunt.

êkwah aw îskwêw ômis îtêyihtam :
mâskôc kinwêsk êh-nîsiyâhk nisîmis , mâskôc aw êkwah êh-akâwâsit , itêyimêw osîma ; Then the woman thought thus: “Perhaps because my brother and I so long have been alone together, perhaps now he has fallen in love with me,” she thought concerning her brother; LB: This motif accords with the existence of the tabu.
êh-môhcôwit aw îskwêw , kây-itêyimât osîma . because she was silly, she thought thus of her brother.
êkosi aspin kâ-mâciyit osîma . So her brother was off hunting.
êkwah ê-kskêyihtahk ê-wih-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik , pîhtokêw , êh-paminawasot aw îskwêw . When she knew that noon was at hand, she went indoors, and prepared her meal.
ê-wîh-mîcisot , mwêhcih êh-kîsi-paminawasot , kîtahtawê kêkway pêhtam ; As she was about to eat, just as she had done cooking, she heard something;
âpihtâ-kîsikâhk itêhkêy isi kâ-pêhtahk êh-pê-nikamoyit awiya . in the direction of noon she heard someone who came a-singing.
piyisk kisiwâk . At last he came near.
êkosi mâna k-êtihtâkosiyit nisîm otasâma , itêyihtam . “Even so my brother's snowshoes always sound,” she thought.
kisiwâk êh-pêy-ihtâyit , kiskowêyiwa . When he had come near, he ceased from his song.
êkwah mosis êkwah pê-pimohtêyiwa . And now he was in sight, walking hither.
pêyakwanohk apiw . She sat still.
ôt êskwâhtêmihk êh-pê-takohtêyit , otasâmiyiwa êkotah âsosimêyiwa . When he came to the doorway, there he leaned upon his snowshoes. LB has {ôt êskwâhtêmihk} as a single word
êh-pê-pîhtokêyit , mitoni naspitawêyiwa osîma . When he came inside, greatly he resembled her brother.

seg.gloss: “From of old my wife sits here!

p.seg: êh-pê-nâtitân oma ! k-êtikot . It is to fetch you I have come!” he told her.
osîmah ôhi k-êsinâkwaniyikih otayôwinisiyiwa , êkos isinâkwaniyiwa otayôwinisiyiwa . As looked those clothes of her brother's, so looked this person's clothes.
mîn ôm ôstikwâniyiw êkos îsinâkwaniyiw . His head, too, looked exactly so.
namoya kitotêw aw îskwêw . The woman did not speak to him.

âsay mîna ,
wawêyî ! êh-pê-nâtitân ôma ! ê-wîh-wîkimitân ! k-êtwêyit . Again, “Get ready! It is to fetch you I have come!” he said to her.

ômis îtwêw aw îskwêw :
namoya êkosi êh-itêyihtamân , kâ-wîh-kakwê-ohpikihitân , nisîmis ! itwêw aw îskwêw . Thus spoke the woman: “It was not with the like of this in mind that I did my best to bring you up, my brother!” she said.
êkosi k-âti-pasikôt awa nâpêw . At that the man rose to his feet.
hâw , kê-wâpahk âpihtâ-kîsikâki , nika-takosinin , ta-pê-mawinêhwak nîci-mîkisistikwân , k-êtwêyit ; “Very well, tomorrow at noon I shall come to challenge my fellow Wampum-Head,” he said;

cikêm âni itah awiyak nama nikitotik , k-êtwêyit , êh-ati-wayawiyit , êh-ati-otinâyit otasâmiwa , êkos êh-ati-pa-postasâmêyit . “Seeing that everywhere else no one ever speaks to me,” he said, and went out of the lodge, taking his snowshoes as he went, and putting them on.
mayaw êy-ati-sipwêhtêyit , k-âti-nikamoyit asâma . As soon as he started away, the snow-shoes began to sing.
mistahi mihtâtam aw îskwêw ôhi êh-kitotât nâpêwa , âta êh-kîh-wîhtamâkot osîma . Very sorry was the woman that she had spoken to this man in spite of her brother's instruction.
pôtih âpihtaw êh-otâkosik kâ-pêhtawât nâtakâm ohci êh-pê-nikamoyit asâma . Then, in the middle of the afternoon she heard snowshoes come singing from the north.
êkonih êkwah osîma , mâka mîna êh-âpohtêyit . It was her brother, bringing, as always, a treat of game.
mâka mîna otasâmiyiwa êh-têhciwêpinâyit , kâ-kitôyit asâma . When he threw his snowshoes, as always, on the wood, the snowshoes gave a call.
êh-pê-pîhtokêyit , mistahi mihtâtam ê-kîh-kitotât ôhi nâpêwa . As he came into the lodge, deeply she regretted that she had spoken to that man.
ê-kîh-nahapiyit osîma , asamêw . When her brother had sat down, she gave him his meal.
êkwah êh-mîcisoyit , wiya atoskâtam ôhi wiyâsah kâ-pêtâyit osîma , êy-âh-akotât wayawîtimihk . While he ate, she worked at the meats which he had brought, hanging them out of doors.
êyikohk ê-kîs-atoskêt , êh-pîhtokêt , êkwah nahastâw otoyâkaniwa , âsay ê-kîsi-mîcisoyit . When she had finished her work, she went indoors and put away her brother's dishes, for he had done eating.
nimisê , tâpwê kikitimahin , kâ-kitotat ana nâpêw , itwêyiwa ; “Sister, truly, you have brought me to an evil pass by speaking to that man,” he said;
namoy âna ê-wîh-wîkimisk , itik ; “His purpose is not to marry you,” he told her;

seg.q: hâw , takohtêci , wâpahki , pê-mawinêhoci , ôtah nik-oh-kotâwaskamikîn ;
seg.gloss: “Now then, when tomorrow he comes to challenge me, at this spot I shall sink into the ground;
he, in turn, will do the same.

seg.q:
pîhtokêci , wîh-mawinêhoci ,
kiya nîkân ! nik-êtâw ani .
seg.gloss: When he comes into the lodge to challenge me, ‘You first!’ I shall say to him.
If he complies, there he will sink into the ground;
and right here where I sit he will stick out his head from the ground.
At that I shall slash off his head.
He head will fall to one side.
Do you then take his head.
I shall hold fast to the body.

seg.q: mâka , êkâ ôtinamani ôma mistikwân , kâwi ta-tâpiskôpayiyiw ostikwân .
seg.gloss: But, if you do not take the head, his head will fly back into place.
In this way he will overcome me.
There, that is the way of it, sister!”

p.seg: â , sêkisiw aw îskwêw . Oh, that woman was frightened.

seg.q: piyisk niya mîna êkosi nika-tôtên , ta-kotâwaskamikiyân .
seg.gloss: “Then I, too, shall do the same, I shall sink into the ground.
He will do the same thing to me.
Then at once he will take my head with him out of the lodge.

seg.q: kîspin êkos îspayikih , sâkôcîhicih , itêh kâ-pahkisimohk , êkotê tit-ôhtohtêw nâpêw .
seg.gloss: If this happens, if he defeats me, then from the direction of the setting sun will come a man.
All his garments will be made of red.
He will come to fetch you; he will marry you.

p.seg:
tâpwêhtawâhkan êwako , êh-miywâtisit , itik osîma aw îskwêw ;
hâh , êkosi , nimisê ! Give credence to him, for he is good,” her brother told her; “there, that is the way of it, my sister!”
piyis êkosi tipiskâyiw . At last night came.
piyis kawisimôwak . At last they went to bed.

êh-wâpahk , ê-kîh-waniskât , êkwah êh-kîh-mîcisocik , mitonih nânapâcihôw aw oskinîkiw , êh-wawêsit . In the morning, when he got up and when they had eaten, the youth made a careful toilet and put on his finery.
pîsk kêkâc âpihtâ-kîsikâyik , namoya kêkway atoskâtam aw îskwêw , êh-kaskêyihtahk ; It was almost noon, but the woman did not work at anything, for she was unhappy;

ôm ôsîma ,
mâskôc nka-sâkôcihik , k-êtwêyit , êwakô tahkih êh-mâ-mitonêyihtah . she brooded without cease on her brother's words, “Perhaps he will defeat me.”
piyisk âpihtâ-kîsikâyiw , âsay kâ-pêtwêwîtamiyit , êh-pê-nikamoyit asâma . At last it was noon, and already that person came noising it, snowshoes a-singing.

hêh , itêyihtam ,
miton êcik ôma êh-kakêpâtisiyân , ‘nisîm êtokê ,’ kâ-kîh-itêyihtamân ! itêyihtam . “Alas,” she thought, “It is plain that I was most stupid to think, ‘Perhaps it is my brother!’” she thought.
ôtah ê-pê-takohtêyit oskinîkiw , ôtah iskwâhtêmihk âsosimêyiwa tasâmiyiwa . When the youth arrived there, he leaned up his snowshoes in the doorway.

êh-pê-pîhtokêyit ,
yah , nîci-mîkisistikwân , êh-pê-mawinêhotân ! k-êtwêyit . When he came into the lodge, “Ha, my fellow Wampum-Head, I have come to challenge you!” he said.
âhag ! itwêyiwa osîma . “Yes!” spoke her brother.
êh-kitâpamât , tâpiskôc pêyak ayîsiyiniw êkos îsinâkosiyiwa . When she looked at them, they looked like one and the same person.
hâ , kiya nîkân , nîci-mîkisistikwân ! itimâwa osîma . “Ha, you first, my fellow Wampum-Head!” her brother was told.
âh ! namoya ! kiya nîkân ! kiya kipê-mêtawân , itwêyiwa osîma . “Ha! No! You first! It is you have come to play,” said her brother.

seg.gloss: “Very well!”

p.seg: kitâpamêw . She watched him.

itah êh-apiyit , êkotah wêh-kotâwaskamikiyit , osîma itahk êh-ôhtiskawâpiyit , êkotah wê-sâkiskwêyit , osîma omôhkomâniyiw ohci kîskikwêwêpahwêyiwa . There where he sat, there he sank into the earth, and there in front of her brother as he sat, there he came sticking out his head, and her brother with his knife slashed through the other's neck.
itêh k-âpit aw îskwêw , êkotah pahkihtin ôma ostikwân . Toward where the woman sat fell that head of his.
otami-tapasîw aw îskwêw ; namoya otinam . She was taken up with fright; she did not seize it.
ôm ôstikwân kâwi êkotah tâpiskopayiyiw . That head of his went back into place.
êkosi pimâtisiyiwa . Thereupon he was alive.
pê-wayawiyiwa ; kâw êkotê nahapiyiwa . He emerged from the earth; he sat down again in his place.
hâw , kiyêskoc mâka ! k-êtimiht osîma . “There, but now it is your turn!” her brother was told.
wawêyiyiwa ; itah k-âpiyit osîma , êkotah wêh-kotâwaskamikiyit osîma . He made ready, from where her brother sat, he sank into the earth.
nêhi kâ-pê-mêtawêyit itah k-ês-ôhtiskawapiyit , êkotah kâ-sâkiskwêt osîma . In front of where he sat who had come to play, there her brother stuck out his head from under the earth.

êh-kiskikwêwêpahomiht osîma , itêh êh-pahkihtiniyik otinam aw oskinîkiw , êh-ati-wayawît . When her brother's head had been slashed off, that youth took it from where it fell, and started out of the lodge.

itah nâh awiyak kiy-ô-sâkôcihit ! itwêyiwa , êh-ati-sipwêhtêyit , ê-sipwêhtatâyit ôhô mistikwân . “There is the one who, of all anywhere, could defeat me!” he said, as he started to go away, taking with him that head.
êkwah ma-mawimôw , êh-mâtot , osîma ostikwâniyiw ê-sipwêhtatâwiht . Then she lamented, weeping, because her brother's head was taken away.
otinam osîma wiyawiyiw , êh-astât ohtapiwiniyih . She took up her brother's body, and placed it upon his settee.
namoya nipiw , êh-âtah-sipwêhtatâwiht ostikwân . He did not die, even though his head had been taken away.
yêhyêyiwa , ê-pa-pimisiniyit ohtapiwiniyihk . He breathed, as he lay there, on his couch.

êkwah tahk êh-mâtot aw îskwêw , piyisk kinwêsk êkotah ayâw , tahkih êh-yêhyêyit osîma ; mâka nama kêkway ostikwân . Then, weeping without respite, at last a long time that woman stayed there, her brother all the while breathing; but he had no head.
êkosi kîtahtawê kâ-takohtêyit nâpêw , pahkisimôtâhk êy-ohtohtêyit . Then, at one time, there arrived a man who came from the region of the setting sun.

ê-pîhtokêyit , tâpwê piko ohtapiwinihk nahapiyiwa ,
êh-pê-nâtitân ; ê-wîh-wîkimitân , êh-itikot . When he came into the lodge, really, he sat down directly upon her couch, saying to her, “I have come to fetch you; I mean to marry you.”
sêmâk nisitawêyimêw êwakoni kâ-kih-itikot osîma . At once she recognized him as the one of whom her brother had told her.

êhag , itêw ;
pitah ka-mîcisonânaw , itêw . “Yes,” she said to him; “But first let us eat,” she said to him.
tâpwê paminawasôw . Accordingly she cooked a meal.
êh-kîsi-paminawasot , êkwah mîcisôwak . When she had prepared her meal, they ate.

êh-kîsi-mîcisocik ,
hâw , wawêyiy êkwah , itik . When they had eaten, “Come, make ready now,” he told her.
êkosi wawêyîw . So she made herself ready.

pitah nika-pônên , êkâ tit-âhkwacit nisîm , itwêw aw îskwêw , êh-wayawît , nêô êh-otinât yôskîhtakwah , êyakonih êh-pônât . “First I must put fuel on the fire, that my brother may not freeze,” said the woman, and went out of the lodge; she took four sticks of crumbling wood and put them on the fire.

haw , itwêw , êh-pakitinât ,
êkâya wîhkâc âstawih ! - hâw , êkosi ! “There,” she said, as she set them down, “Never go out! Well, I am ready!”
wayawîw . She went out.

kahkiyaw pîhcâyihk oma wîkiwâw k-âstêkih nakatam aw îskwêw , ê-sipwêhtêcik , êh-kîwêhtahikot . The woman left behind in their lodge all the things that were there, and they departed, that man taking her with him in his home.
êkosi nêtê , kêkâc êh-tipiskâk , takosin wîkiwâhk awa nâpâw . Accordingly, over yonder, at nightfall, that man arrived at their dwelling.
pôtih misâyiw wîkih awa nâpêw , kahkiyaw êh-mihkwahikâtêyik . She saw that his lodge was a large one and that it had been made entirely red.

seg.gloss: “Now dwell here!”

p.seg: tâpwê miywêyihtam aw îskwêw êh-wîcêwât nâpêwa . Truly, the woman was glad to be with the man.
mistahi kakâyawisiw awa nâpêw , pisisik êh-mâcît , awa mîna iskwêw kahkiyaw kêkway êy-osîhtât . The man was very industrious, hunting all the time, and the woman, too, made all manner of things.

piyis kinwêsk êh-owîhcêhtocik , kîtahtawê kiskêyihtam aw îskwêw êh-wîh-ayâwât awâsisah , piyisk ê-misikitit . At last, when they had been married for a long time, she knew that she was going to have a child; [no translation]
êkoyikohk awa nâpêw kiskêyihtam . Then the man knew it.
hâw , namoya nika-mâcîn , itwêw ; “Very well, I shall not hunt,” he said,

seg.gloss: “You would be working too much.

seg.q: êkwah awâsis ê-wîh-ayâwat , namoya nintawêyihtên t-âtoskêyin .
seg.gloss: Now that you are going to have a child, I do not want you to work.

p.seg: mâskôc wih-ohpikicih aw âwâsis kâ-wîh-ayâwâyahk , itêw . Perhaps the child we are to have will grow up,” he told her. LB: Rationalized or rudimentary couvade?
êhag , itêw aw îskwêw . “Yes,” the woman answered him.
tâpwê namoya mistahi ôh-atoskêw , êkâ ta-misi-wanâcihât ôh âwâsisah . Accordingly, from that time on she did not work much, so as not to injure that child.
piyisk kîtahtawê êkwah âhkosiw aw îskwêw , ê-wîh-wâpamât awâsisah . Then in time the woman fell ill, as she was about to see her child.
tâpwê piyisk tawâsimisiw , pôtih nâpêsisah . Then, finally, she bore her child, and it turned out to be a boy.

kîtahtawê ,
tâpiskôc kotak , itêyihtam . Presently, “It seems as if there were another,” she thought.
miyâmay mîna pêyak , itêw onâpêma . “Surely there is one more,” she told her husband.
tâpwê min êyakoni wâpamêwak . Really, they saw this one, too.
min êyako nâpêsis . This one, too, was a boy.
nîsôtêwak ayâwêwak . They had twins.
miywêyihtam awa nâpêw , mîn âw îskwêw . The man was glad, and the woman too.
êkwah nama wîhkâc mâcîw awa nâpêw , pâh-pêyak êh-pamihâcik ocawâsimisiwâwa . Then the man never hunted, each of them taking care of one of their children.
piyisk kinwês itah êy-ayâcik , piyisk misikitisiwak awâsisak ôki . At last, when they had been there a long time, those children grew bigger.
êkwah êh-pimohtêcik awâsisak ôki , otôskwanisiwâhk môhkomânah sâkikiniyiwa ôki nâpêsisak . Then, when those children had begun to walk, knives grew forth from the elbows of those boys.
mitoni mâmaskâtamwak otawâsimisiwâwa êh-môhkomânitôskwanêyit . They wondered greatly at their children's having knife-elbows.
kiyipa misikitiwak . Quickly they grew up.
êkwah atoskêwak , awa nâpêw êh-mâh-mâcît . Then they worked, as the man hunted.
awa mîna iskwêw atoskêw êkwah . The woman, too, now worked.
êkwah ôk âwâsisak pisisik ma-mêtawêwak , acosisah êh-ayâcik , êw-ohci-mêtawêcik . And those children always played, having arrows with which to play.
kîtahtawê mâna namoya wâpamêw awa iskwêw ocawâsimisah kâ-kapê-kîsik . Then, in time, the woman would not see her children all day.
êyikohk wêtâkosiniyikih , êkoyikohk takohtêyiwah ocawâsimisah . Only just before evening the children would come home.

kîtahtawê ,
ka-wanisininâwâw ! itêw ocawâsimisah . Presently, “You will get lost!” she told her children.
piyisk misikitiwak ôki nâpêsisak . At last those boys grew to full size.

kîtahtawê mâka mina êh-îkatêhtêyit , êh-âkawêwêyit , wîh-kakwê-wâpamêw aw îskwêw okosisah . Then at one time, when in their usual way they had walked off and out of sight, the woman decided to try to observe her sons.

ômisi k-êtwêyit :
hâh , nisîmis ! mahti mîna nitawâpamâtân kisisinaw ! k-êtwêyit . One of them said, “Come, younger brother! Let us go again to see our uncle!”
êkoyikohk kâ-kiskisit osîma , aspin kâ-kîh-kîskikwêwêpahomiht . At last she remembered her brother, who had had his head cut off the last she had seen of him.
êh-pimotahkwêyit , aspin wîpisisiyihk kîh-ati-nîpawiyiwa . Her sons shot arrows, and off they sailed, standing on their arrows.
êkos îsi kîwêw . Thereupon she went home.

namoy êkwah wîh-atoskêw , êh-ay-apit , êh-mâ-mitonêyihtah aspin êh-kitimahimiht osîma . She did not care now to work, but sat there, thinking of how her brother had been undone when last she had seen him.
êyikohk ê-wîh-tipiskâyik , kâ-takohtêyit oskosisah . Not until nightfall did her sons come home.

seg.q: kêkway oma mâna êh-nâtamêk , kâ-kapê-kîsik êkâ kâ-takosiniyêk ?
seg.gloss: “What is it you always go after, when all day you do not come home?”

p.seg: mâka kiskêyimik êh-kitâpamât okosisah , aspin kâ-sipwêhtêyit , k-ôti-nîpawiyit wîpisisiyihk . But her sons knew that she had observed them as they went off standing on their arrows.

ômis îtik :
nêkâ , ôtêh oma mâna êh-itohtêyâhk , pêyak mîkiwâhp êh-ayâk , ayîsiyiniw êh-pêyakot , êkâ êy-ostikwânit , êkw âna mâna êh-ntawâpamâyâhk , êkâw ôma k-âpiyâhk , itik . Thus they answered her: “Mother, because we always go off there, to where there is a solitary lodge, where one man stays alone, who has no head because we visit him, that is why, as you say, we do not stay at home,” they told her.
mâtôw aw îskwêw . She wept.

iyikohk êh-pôni-mâtot , ômis îtêw :
ncawâsimisitik , kisisiwâw ana ; nisîmis ana ; When she stopped weeping, she said to them, “My children, he is your mother's brother; he is my younger brother;

seg.q: mistah âna ê-kîh-miyosit , ê-kîh-mîkisiwiyik ostikwân , mâka ê-kîh-mawinêhokot wîci-mîkisistikwâna , aspin ê-kî-sipwêhtatâyit ostikwân .
seg.gloss: he was very handsome, and beaded was his head, but his fellow Wampum-Head challenged him to a contest and carried off his head.
Is he still breathing!”
seg.note: LB ad {kêyâpi cîh}: For {kêyâpic cîh}; so usually in close-knit phrases of rapid speech when final and initial {ts} come together.

p.seg: êhag ; kêyâpic yêhyêw , itik okosisah . “Yes; he still breathes,” her sons told her.

ômis îtwêw aw ôsîmimâs :
nistêsê , êyakw êcik ânimah ôtêh ôtênaw k-âyâk , anah pîhtêyask kâ-wîkit , êyakw êcik ânima ispimihk k-âkotêk , itah kâhkâkiw k-âkosît , The younger brother spoke as follows: “Elder brother, plainly it appears that it is none other than that which, in the town over there, hangs aloft over the dwelling of him who lives in the centre, there where the raven sits aloft,”

itwêw aw ôsîmimâs :
hâ , kê-wâpahk mîna ka-nitawâpamânaw kisisinaw , itwêw aw ôsîmimâs . said the younger brother; “Come, tomorrow let us again visit our uncle,” said the younger lad.

seg.gloss: “Very well.”

p.seg: tâpwê êh-otâkosik , takosin awa nâpêw , ê-kîh-mâcît . At nightfall that man arrived from his hunt.
owîkimâkanah ka-kamwâtapiyiwa . His wife was sitting and brooding.
tânêhki , niwîkimâkan ? itêw . What is the matter, my wife?” he asked her.

nâ , ôk ôki kicawâsimisinawak kâ-kapê-kîsik êkâ k-âpicik , k-êtitân mâna , ês ôki osisiwâwa êh-mân-itohtêcik , êyakoni êh-âcimostawicik , k-ôh-kamwâtapiyân , itwêyiwa . “Dear me, when these children of ours, as I always am telling you, stay out all day, it seems that they always go to where their uncle is, and now they have told me it, and that is why I sit and grieve,” she said.

êkosi tâpwê êh-tipiskâyik , êh-nipâcik , êh-wâpahk , kîksêpâ âsay mîna sipwêhtêyiwa ocawâsimisiwâwa . Then, when night came, and they had slept, then in the morning early, again their children went off.
êkwah namoya wîh-kitahamawêw aw îskwêw otawâsimisah . And now the woman did not care to stop her children.

êh-ntawâpamâcik ôki awâsisak osisiwâwa , êkotê êh-takohtêcik , ê-kîh-pônahkik , ômis îtwêw aw ostêsimâs :
hâ , nsîmis , mahti niya nîkân nika-kakwê-nâtên kisisinaw ostikwân , itêw . When those children went to see their uncle, and had come there and built up the fire, the elder boy said, “Now, younger brother, let me first try to get our uncle's head.”

seg.gloss: “Very well.”

p.seg: hâ , nsîmis , kîspin pêtâyâni , kakwê-waniskâpitâhkan kisisinaw , itêw . “Well then, brother, if I come bringing it, try to pull our uncle to his feet,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg:
êkos ê-ati-wayawît aw oscêsimâs , êkotah skwâhtêmihk êh-ayât ,
hâw , oskac ê-kîh-itêyihtamân tit-ômicaskosîsîwiyân ! Then, as the elder brother was going out of the lodge, as he stood in the doorway, “Now, at the very first I did think that I should be a swallow!”

tâpwê ahpihyâw , êh-pimihât êkotê kâ-kîh-wâpahtahk osisah ostikwâniyiw . Really, he rose into the air and flew to where he had seen his uncle'e head. beginning of second word (ahpihyaw?) is obscured in the book.
êkotê êh-takohtêt , cîki mwêhci êh-ihtât , kâ-kitoyit ôhi kâhkâkiwa . When he got there, just as he was near, that raven croaked.

êkos âwa kâ-mîkisistikwânêt wayawîw , êh-têpwêt ,
kiwîh-maskamikawinânaw nikâhkwâskwahikan ! êh-itwêt . At that the wampum-headed one came out of the lodge, and hallooed, crying, “Someone is trying to rob us of my lodge-emblem!”

êkosi tapasîw awa omîtaskosîs , êkwah ê-nawaswâtiht , êh-kîwê-mâkohiht , ayis atimihcih ta-nipahiht . Then that swallow fled, and was pursued and close pressed on his way home, for if he were overtaken, he would be killed.
êkosi piyisk takosin osîmisah itah k-âyâyit . At last he arrived where his younger brother was.
êkosi pônihâw . Then he was left alone.

êkwah aw ôsîmimâs ômis îtêw :
tânsi tiyôtaman ? itêw ostêsah . Then the younger lad spoke to him; “How did you fare?” he asked his elder brother.

seg.q: hâ , mayaw cîkih êh-ayâyân , âsay kitôw ana kâhkâkîw ; nimôsihikawin .
seg.gloss: “Ho, just as I got close, that raven croaked; my coming was perceived.”

p.seg: kah ! â , mahti niya ! itwêw aw ôsîmimâs . “Well! Now, let me try!” said the younger lad.
êkwah aw ôsîmimâs wayawîw . Then the younger brother went out of the lodge.
hâw , oskac ê-kî-htêyihtamân ta-kêhkêhkowiyân ! itwêw . “Now, at the very first I did think that I should be a hawk!” he said.
tâpwê kêhkêhkôwiw ; ohpihyâw , êy-ispihât . So he turned into a hawk; he rose into the air, flying high.
êkotê êh-takosihk , ispimihk ohci môskîstawêw ôhi kâhkâkiwah . When he came to that place, from on high he attacked the raven.
kâhkâkiw awa ispîh êh-wâpamât , namoya wîh-kitôw , êh-kostât kêhkêhkwah . When the raven saw him, it would not croak, for it feared the hawk.
ôma ostikwân manipitam awa kêhkêhk , êkos êh-tapasît . The hawk snatched that head and made off in flight.
êyikohk wâhyaw êh-ihtât , êkoyikohk kitoyiwa . Not until he was far on his way did the raven croak.
iyâtah-wayawîpahtât awa , âsay wâhyaw kîh-atimihâyiwa . Though that person came running forth from the lodge, by this time the other had flown far off on his course.

êhêhê ! itwêw ;
nawaswêk , nawaswêk ! kimaskamikawinânaw nôstikwânim ! itwêw . “Alas!” he cried; “Go in pursuit! We have been robbed of my head!” he cried.
nanâtohk itôwiwiwak , êh-nawaswêcik . They turned into all manner of creatures, as they went in pursuit.
mîhkawikiw kêhkêhk ; nakatêw kahkiyaw ôhi kâ-pimihâyit . The hawk was swift; he left behind all that fly in the air.

cîk êh-ihtât , ômis îtwêw :
nistêsêh , yôhtêwêpinah ! kakwê-waniskâpis kisisinaw ! itêw . When he came near, he cried, “Brother, open the door! Try to pull our uncle to his feet!” he told him.

tâpwê ê-yôhtêwêpinahk , êkwah ôhi ê-wîh-kakwê-waniskânât , êkoyikohk kisiwâk êkwah ayâw . When, accordingly, the other threw open the door and made ready to pull him to his feet, by that time he was close by.
êwakwê , nistêsê ! sinikohkitonêpis ! itêw . “Here it comes, brother! Rub his mouth!” he told him.
tâpwê tâpiskopayiw om ostikwân , êkwah aw ôstêsimâs ê-sinikohkitonênât . Truly, that head flew into place, and the elder lad rubbed his mouth.
êkosi pimâtisiw . So he came to life.
kâ-nawaswêcik ôki kahkiyaw kîwêwak . All those who had given chase went back.
miywêyihtamwak ôki nâpêsisak êh-pimâtisiyit osisiwâwa . Those boys rejoiced that their uncle had come to life.

seg.gloss: “Now then, let us go home! Let us take our uncle home!”

p.seg: â , wayawîwak . They stepped out of the lodge.

owîpisisah êkwah otastotinah , êyakonih piko otinam awa kâ-mîkisiwiyik ostikwân , êkos êh-wayawîcik . His arrows and his head-dress, only these he took whose head was beaded, as they stepped forth from the lodge.

seg.gloss: “Now, younger brother, let me be the one to take our uncle.”
“Very well.”

p.seg:
hâ , êh-pimotahkwêt ,
hâw , nisis , ôtah nk-âti-nîpawinân . Then, shooting an arrow, “Come, uncle, on this we others shall stand as we go.

seg.gloss: In the grove this side of where we live, there we shall come to earth.”

p.seg: tâpwê pimih-nîsokâpawiwak wîpisisihk . Truly they went along, two of them standing on his arrow.
êh-otâkosik , êkotah pahkisinok , êkotah ohci ê-pimohtêcik . Toward evening they came to earth there, and from that point walked on.

aw îskwêw wayawitimihk êh-atoskêt , kîtahtawê kâ-pê-sâkêwêyit osîma êkwah otawâsimisah , âyîtaw êh-pê-pmohtêcik ôk âwâsisak osisiwâwa . As that woman was at work out of doors, presently she beheld coming forth her brother and her children, the children walking at either side of their uncle.

sêmâk aw îskwêw ,
hây hây ! nisîmis pimâtisiw ! itêw , ê-takohtêyit , êh-atamiskawât , êkwah êh-pîhtokêcik , êh-ati-kîsitêpot aw îskwêw . At once that woman said to him, “Goodness! My brother is alive!” and went to welcome him, and they went indoors and she set about preparing a feast.
kîtahtawê kâ-pîhtokêyit owîkimâkana . Presently her husband came in.

hay hay hay ! itêw ;
tâpwê âyimâc niwâpamâw nîstâw ! itwêw awa nâpêw . “Splendid, splendid!” he said to him; “Truly, after long delay I see my wife's brother!” said that man.
êkosi êkotah ayâwak . So they stayed there.

pisisik êh-mêtawâkêcik osisiwâwa , namoya êkwah wîhkâc kont îtê itohtêwak ôki awâsisak , osisiwâwa ê-wîci-mêtawêmâcik pîhcâyihk . Those children did nothing but play with their uncle, and now never went off anywhere, but played with their uncle indoors.
êkâ tôtâhk kisisiwâw ! mistahi kimêtawâkânâwâw ! êh-itât aw îskwêw ocawâsimisah , “Do not thus with your uncle! You treat him too much as your play-fellow!” said the woman to her children,
hâ , namoya ! itwêw aw ôskinîkiw ; but, “No!” said that youth;
kiyâm nka-mêtawâkâtikwak nitêhkwatimak ; êwakonik k-ôh-pimâtisiyân , itêw omisah . “Let my nephews treat me as their comrade at play; it is to them I owe my life,” he told his sister.
êkosi piyisk kinwêsk ayâwak . So at last they were there a long time.
awa nâpêw pisisik mâcîw . That man was always hunting.
kîtahtawê namoya takosin . Then at one time he did not come home.

êh-wâpahk , êkâ êh-takosihk ,
mahtih , nitêhkwatimitik , nka-nitonawâw kôhtâwiyiwâw , itêw . When he had not arrived by the next morning, “Now, my nephews, I shall look for your father,” he told them.

seg.gloss: “Very well.”

p.seg: tâpwê nitonawêw . So he sought him.
pôt êsah kâh-mâtâhâyit môswa ; êyakonih mitihtêyiwa wîstâwa . it appeared he had come upon the trail of a moose; this moose his brother-in-law had tracked.
pôtih wâpahtam êy-osêtinâyik , ê-pasâhcâyik êkotah , môhkiciwanipêk êh-ayâyik . At last he saw a hill over a ravine in which was a spring of water.
êkotah êsa kâ-kî-tohtêyit wîstâwa . To that place it seemed that his brother-in-law had gone.

êh-otihtahk , itah ohcih kâ-wayawîciwaniyik , kâ-pê-sâkiskwêyit misi-kinêpikwah , êh-tâwatiyit , êh-otatâmikot , ê-misiwêpayihikot . When he came to it, then from where the spring flowed forth, a Great Serpent thrust out its head with gaping jaws, and drew him in and swallowed him bodily.
awên ôhi , êkotêh kîh-apiyiwa wîstâwa , namoya êh-nipiyit . Whom did he see but his brother-in-law sitting there, alive.
wîstah namoya nipiw . He, too, did not die.
wîtapimêw wîstâwah , piyis êtokê êh-tipiskâyik . He sat with his brother-in-law, until it must have been night.

êh-wâpaniyik , êka êh-takosihk , ôhi nîsôtêwak , aw ôstêsimâs ,
mahtih nka-ntonawâw ksisinaw ! When he did not come home by next morning, of those twins the elder, “Let me go look for our uncle!”
awahê , nistêsê ! itwêw aw ôsîmimâs . “Be on your guard, my brohter!” said the younger lad.
êkosi sipwêhtêw aw oscêsimâs . Accordingly the elder brother set out.
pôtih itah êsah k-âti-mitihtâyit môswah , êkotah at-ay-itohtêw . There where it appeared that his father had trailed the moose, there he walked on.
piyisk otihtam ôma môhkiciwanipêk . At last he came to that spring.
cîk êh-ihtât , kâ-pê-sâkiskwêyit misi-kinêpikwa , êh-tâwatiyit , êh-otatâmikot . When he came near, the Great Serpent thrust forth its head, gaping, and sucked him in.

êh-papêtikopayihot , ôhi otôskwanihk môhkomânah kâ-sâkikiniyikih ,
êwakoni nik-ôh-mâtiswâw , êy-itêyihtahk , naspâc isiwêpinam ôhi , ê-misiwêpayihiht . When he doubled himself up, thinking of the knives that grew forth from his elbows, “With these I shall cut him to pieces,” he swung them awkwardly, and was swallowed whole.
pôt ôhi osisah kiy-apiyiwa , êkwah ôhtâwiyah . There sat his uncle and his father.
êkosi mîna tipiskâyiw . Thus came another night.
êh-wâpahk , aw êkw ôsîmimâs kâ-sipwêhtêt , êh-ntonawât ostêsah . In the morning the younger brother set out to look for his elder brother.
pôtih êsa kâ-mitihtât môswah . He came to where it appeared that he had trailed a moose.
wîstah mitihtêw . He too trailed it.

môhkiciwanipêk êh-otihtahk , cîki êh-ayât , ôm îtah k-ôh-pê-sâkiskwêyit misi-kinêpikwah , mâka mîna pê-sâkiskwêyiwa . When he came to the spring, as he got near to where the Great Serpent had thrust forth its head, again it thrust out its head.
êwakoni kâ-misi-wanâchikocik , itêyihtam . “This is the one who destroyed them,” he thought.
êh-tâwatiyit , ê-wih-otatâmikot , pâyakwanohk nîpawiw . As it opened wide its jaws to draw him in, he stood still in place.
iyâta-tâwatiyici , namoya kîh-ispayiw . No matter how much it opened its jaws, it could not make him come that way.
sôhkih , misi-kinêpik ! tâwatih ! pê-wayawîh ! itêw . “Courage, Great Serpent! Open your jaws! Come out a bit farther!” he said to it.
iyâtah-itwêyicih , ê-wîh-otatâmikot , namawya kaskihik . Though he continued to encourage it to draw him in, it could not get hold of him.

tahkih ayiwâkês êh-pê-wayawiyit ,
sôhkih ! êh-itât , sôhk êh-tâwatiyit , papêtikôpayihôw , ômis îsi âyîtaw ê-isiwêpinahk otôskwanah . It kept coming out farther and farther, and he said to it, “Courage!” and it stretched its jaws as far as it could; he doubled himself up and swung his elbows out at both sides, like this.
mitoni tâskiswêw ôhi misi-kinêpikwah . He cut the Great Serpent all to strips.
awên ôhi , ostêsah osisah ôhtâwiya êkotah ohci pê-wayawiyiwa . Whom did he see but his brother, his uncle and his father, coming out from there!
nipahêw ayisk ôhi ; êkosi kîwêhtahêw . For he had slain that creature; so now he brought them home.
kîwêwak ; êh-tipiskâyik takosinwak wîkiwâhk . They went home; at nightfall they arrived at their dwelling.

êkwah êh-wâpahk , ômis îtwêw osîmimâs awa :
hâw , osâm kimôhcôwin , nistêsê . Then, the next morning, thus spoke that younger lad: “Now then, you are too foolish, my elder brother.

seg.q: namoya ês âni kimanitôwin ; pisisik kisâkôcihikawin .
seg.gloss: It seems that you have no manitou power; you are always being defeated.
It will be better if I tell you what I have planned.”
“Very well.”

seg.q: hâw , nôhtâh , kiyawâw nikâwiy : cêskwah ayîsiyiniwak tit-êhtâwak ;
seg.gloss: “Well then, my father, as for you and my mother: soon there will be mortal men;
in future time you will stay on the hills;
you will be tall;

p.seg:
okiniyak k-êsiyîhkâsonâwâw , itêw ôhtâwiyah êkwah okâwiyah ,
osâm êh-miyo-pimâtisiyêk.
thorn-trees you will be called,” he told his father and his mother, “because you are good beings.

seg.q: êkwah kiya , nisisê , ôtêh êh-pahkisimohk , êkotê kik-ôtaskîn .
seg.gloss: And you, my uncle, over here in the place of the setting sun, there you will have your habitation.
‘The man with the beaded head has taken pity on me,’ a man will say;
in his sleep he will see you, my uncle.

seg.q: êkwah niyanân : ôtah nîkânês isi tit-âpisîsisiwak acâhkosak ; câh-cîkih tit-âyâwak ;
seg.gloss: And as for us: here, a little ways ahead there will be small stars; they will be near to each other;

p.seg: nik-êkotôwiwinân niyân nistês , itêw ; such will we be, my elder brother and I,” he said to them;

seg.gloss: “There, that is the way of it; be off!”

p.seg: êkosi ôki sipwêhtêwak . Accordingly, those others went off.
waciy êh-otihtahkik awa ôwîkimâkana , kawipayihôwak ; okinîwiwak . When they came to a hill, he and his wife, they threw themselves upon the ground; they turned into thorn-trees.
êkwah ôki nâpêsisak ispimihk itohtêwak , êh-acâhkosiwicik . And those boys went up aloft and turned into stars.
êkosi êkoyikohk êh-iskwâk âtayôhkêwin . And so this is the end of the sacred story.
